prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain Tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Mia Fey
Description: Maya's older sister and my eternal mentor in life and law. Passed away 2 years ago.
Character 2
Name: Godot
Description: A prosecutor who is shrouded in mystery. He seems to know me somehow.
Character 3
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 4
Name: Maggey Byrde
Description: A waitress at Trés Bien. Was found guilty of murder thanks to the phony me.
Character 5
Name: Jean Armstrong
Description: Trés Bien's owner and chef. A witness in the case who is also into aromatherapy.
Character 6
Name: Glen Elg
Description: The victim. Was a programmer. Maggey had apparently never even seen him before.
Character 7
Name: Victor Kudo
Description: Was in Trés Bien at the time of the incident. Has a thing for waitresses.
Character 8
Name: Lisa Basil
Description: The CEO of Blue Screens, Inc., and Glen Elg's boss. Absolutely not a robot.
Character 9
Name: Violetta → Viola Cadaverini
Description: Possibly part of the staff at Tender Lender? A thoroughly bitter person.
Character 10
Name: Furio Tigre
Description: The head of Tender Lender loan company. Also known as "The Tiger".
Character 11
Name: Bruto Cadaverini
Description: The head of the Cadaverini Family crime syndicate. Seems to live for his granddaughter.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: A present from Maya. It reacts to people who have secrets in their hearts. On loan from Maya. Recovered in the kitchen of Trés Bien.
Evidence 2
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An article from December 5th. Says I was trounced and my client was found guilty.
Evidence 3
Name: Sports Paper
Description: Dates from December 3rd, the day of the incident. On it is a doodle that said 'MC Bomber' with an arrow pointing to '100,000' that was crossed out. 'Ahahahaha' and a laughing face are written next to it. Left by a costumer in Trés Bien on Dec. 3rd. Click here for details. Left by the victim. Doodle is in victim's handwriting. Click here for details.
Evidence 4
Name: Job Listings
Description: Picked up from a bench in Vitamin Square. Thrown away by the old man.
Evidence 5
Name: Lunch Special
Description: Trés Bien lunch special. Costs 20 dollars despite how unbelievably bad it tastes.
Evidence 6
Name: Small Bottle
Description: Found in the kitchen. Shape is different from the others bottles. Contents unknown. The victim's ear medicine. Found covered in unidentified fingerprints in the kitchen. The victim's ear medicine. Covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints.
Evidence 7
Name: Scooter
Description: Ridden by my phony. The wheel guard is all smashed up.
Evidence 8
Name: Jean's Loan Contract
Description: Jean's debt is half a million dollars. The owner of the loan is Tender Lender.
Evidence 9
Name: Victor's Note
Description: "Convicted before, a wicked man or woman, repeat offender -- Victor Kudo"
Evidence 10
Name: Glen's Autopsy Report
Description: Died of potassium cyanide poisoning. Time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM.
Evidence 11
Name: Trés Bien Floor Plans
Description: Blueprints of the crime scene. Click here for details. X = victim's seat.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A photo of the scene taken from near the kitchen. Two dining tables are separated by a folding screen. The one closer to the camera is empty. The other one is where the victim collapse on the table. There is an intact vase on each table. A coffee cup is knocked over and the the table cloth is stained by coffee. Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a kind of scary old man, sir.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 1
Testimony: Poor Maggey had passed out from the shock. It must've been real tough for her.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The victim didn't have any identification on him.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 3
Testimony: But we figured out who he was pretty quick, and then the investigation went smoothly.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 4
Testimony: When Maggey was searched, we found the lottery ticket and the bottle of poison.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 5
Testimony: And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene.
Person: Gumshoe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
Alright, let's tackle this problem. We need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants only one pair, so I have to look through all the provided info and spot a contradiction.

First, let's list out the testimonies and see what each one says. Testimony 3 from Gumshoe states that once they figured out the victim's identity, the investigation went smoothly. The key point here is that they identified the victim quickly. But looking at the evidence, let's check if there's something that contradicts this.

Evidence 2 is a Magazine Clipping from December 5th that mentions the user (probably Phoenix Wright) was trounced and the client was found guilty. The date here is important—December 5th, which is two days after the incident on December 3rd. Wait, the crime happened on the 3rd, and the article is from the 5th. But Testimony 3 suggests they identified the victim quickly, allowing the investigation to proceed smoothly. However, if the victim's identity was known immediately, how was there a trial concluded by the 5th? That's a quick turnaround. But maybe that's possible. Not sure if that's the contradiction.

Looking at another angle: Evidence 2's clipping says the client was found guilty. But Maggey (Character 4) was found guilty thanks to the phony me (Phoenix?), so maybe the timeline is off. But how does that tie into Testimony 3?

Wait, Testimony 3 says they identified the victim quickly. Let's check if any evidence suggests the victim's identification wasn't straightforward. Evidence 2 is about the trial outcome, but perhaps another evidence contradicts the quick identification. Evidence 2 might not directly relate to the identification of the victim.

Looking at Evidence 3: Sports Paper from Dec 3rd with a doodle by the victim. The victim's handwriting is on it. So if they found this, they could identify the victim through his handwriting. But Testimony 2 says the victim had no ID, but they figured him out quickly. So maybe that's consistent.

Wait, Testimony 3 says once they knew who he was, the investigation went smoothly. If the victim's identity was established through the doodle (Evidence 3), that's okay. But maybe another evidence contradicts the 'nothing else missing from the crime scene' in Testimony 5. Let's check Testimony 5: "And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene." But Evidence 17 is the Victim's Prescription Bag, which is empty. If the bag was supposed to have medicine, but it's empty, maybe the bottle (Evidence 6) is the ear medicine. Wait, Evidence 6 is the small bottle found in the kitchen, which is the victim's ear medicine. But according to Evidence 17, the prescription bag is empty. So if the victim had a prescription bag that's empty, but the ear medicine was found in the kitchen, maybe that's a missing item. But Testimony 5 says nothing was missing. Hmm, but the prescription bag was on the victim, and the ear medicine was in the kitchen. So maybe the bottle was moved, but not missing. Not sure.

Alternatively, Evidence 14 is the Victim's Lottery Ticket found on Maggey. If the ticket was in the victim's possession, then it being found on Maggey would mean it was taken, contradicting Testimony 5 which says nothing was missing. But Testimony 4 says when Maggey was searched, they found the ticket and poison. So the ticket was on Maggey, implying it was taken from the victim. Therefore, if the ticket was the victim's, then it was missing from the crime scene, contradicting Testimony 5. That could be the contradiction.

So Testimony 5 claims nothing else was missing, but the lottery ticket (Evidence 14) was found on Maggey, implying it was taken from the scene. Therefore, the ticket was missing, contradicting Testimony 5. Therefore, Evidence 14 contradicts Testimony 5.

But let me check the details again. Testimony 4: When Maggey was searched, they found the lottery ticket and the poison. So the ticket was on her person. If the ticket belonged to the victim, then it was removed from the scene and taken by Maggey, making it a missing item. But Testimony 5 says nothing else was missing. So that's a contradiction. So Evidence 14 (Victim's Lottery Ticket found on Maggey) contradicts Testimony 5 (nothing else missing).

Yes, that's a solid contradiction. Therefore, the answer should be Evidence 14 and Testimony 5.

{"evidence": 14, "testimony": 5}

response:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's start by looking through the testimonies and cross-referencing with the evidence.

Testimony 3 by Kudo says that the serving girl (Maggey) brought over the javaccino. But looking at the evidence, the Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has fingerprints from both the victim and Maggey. Wait, but the testimony mentions a "javaccino," which is a specific drink. However, the evidence refers to a coffee cup containing potassium cyanide. Maybe there's a contradiction here because the Coffee Cup is for coffee, not a javaccino? Or perhaps the term "javaccino" is incorrect. Alternatively, maybe the presence of the Coffee Cup's details contradicts something in the testimony.

Looking at Evidence 13: the coffee cup has a lip stain on the front and a floral handle to the right. If the victim was holding a newspaper in his right hand (Testimony 1 says he had a newspaper in his right hand), then when he picked up the cup with his free hand (Testimony 4 says he used his free hand to take a sip), that free hand would be his left hand. But the coffee cup's handle is on the right. If he used his left hand, holding the cup with the handle on the right might be awkward, leading to a possible contradiction. Wait, maybe that's a stretch. Let me check again.

Wait, Testimony 3 says the serving girl brought the javaccino. But the Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) is described as a coffee cup with potassium cyanide. If the drink was a javaccino, which might be a different type of drink, but the evidence refers to coffee. However, maybe "javaccino" is a term used for coffee here. Alternatively, if the javaccino is supposed to be served in a different type of cup, but the evidence shows a coffee cup. Hmm, not sure yet.

Alternatively, let's look at Testimony 2 by Kudo: the young man was listening to the wireless. But the Sports Paper (Evidence 3) mentions a doodle about 'MC Bomber' and the date is Dec 3rd. The victim had a newspaper in his right hand (Testimony 1). If he was holding a newspaper and listening to the wireless (radio) at the same time, maybe that's possible, but not necessarily a contradiction. Not sure.

Another angle: Testimony 4 says the victim took a sip with his free hand (left hand if the right was holding the newspaper). The coffee cup's handle is on the right. If the handle is on the right, a right-handed person would typically hold it with the right hand. But the victim's right hand was holding the newspaper, so he used his left hand. That could mean the handle's position makes it difficult to hold with the left hand. So the positioning of the handle (on the right side of the cup) might contradict the testimony that he used his free (left) hand to pick up the cup. Therefore, the way the cup is designed (handle on the right) would be awkward for a left-handed grip. So Evidence 13 (Coffee Cup) and Testimony 4 might contradict. Wait, but the question is asking for one pair. Let me check the exact details.

Evidence 13's description: "facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right." So the handle is on the right side. If the victim used his left hand to pick up the cup, the handle would be on the opposite side, making it difficult to hold properly. So the presence of the lip stain on the front (assuming the front is where the handle is) might indicate that the cup was held with the right hand. But according to Testimony 4, he used his free hand (left), which would mean the handle is on the wrong side. Therefore, the testimony that he used his left hand contradicts the evidence about the handle's position and the lip stain. So Evidence 13 and Testimony 4 contradict. But I need to check if that's the case.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says the serving girl brought the javaccino. But Evidence 13 is a coffee cup. If "javaccino" is a specific drink that's different from regular coffee, but the cup found is a coffee cup, maybe there's a contradiction. However, the establishment is Trés Bien, which is a café, so maybe they serve javaccino in coffee cups. Not sure.

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 3 and the Coffee Cup's fingerprints. The Coffee Cup has the victim and Maggey's prints. Testimony 3 says Maggey brought the javaccino, which would align with her fingerprints being on the cup. But if the Coffee Cup is the murder weapon with cyanide, and the testimony is that she brought it, that's consistent. So maybe that's not a contradiction.

Wait, another angle: The Small Bottle (Evidence 6) is the victim's ear medicine, but it's covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints. If the victim had a prescription bag (Evidence 17) which is empty, maybe the bottle was taken by someone else. But how does that relate to testimonies?

Alternatively, the Sports Paper (Evidence 3) has a doodle by the victim about 'MC Bomber' linked to 100,000 crossed out and laughing. MC Bomber is a virus (Evidence 23) made by Glen. The doodle's date is Dec 3rd, same as the meeting with The Tiger (Glen's Calendar, Evidence 20). The meeting with "The Tiger" (Furio Tigre) was on the same day. So maybe the victim was planning something with Tigre, but the doodle indicates he was mocking the deal. However, how does this relate to testimonies?

Wait, Testimony 0 by Kudo says the victim was wearing a broken pair of spectacles. But perhaps there's evidence about the victim's vision or something else. Not sure.

Alternatively, the Coffee Cup's fingerprints: Maggey's fingerprints are on it, but the potassium cyanide is in her apron (Evidence 16). If she brought the cup, that's consistent, but the contradiction might be that the Coffee Cup's handle position contradicts how the victim held it. So going back to Testimony 4 and Evidence 13. The testimony says he used his free hand (left) to pick up the cup, but the handle is on the right. If he was right-handed, using the left hand to pick up a cup with a right-handle would be awkward, leading to possible spillage or not holding it properly. The autopsy says he died of poisoning, which was in the coffee. If he couldn't hold the cup properly, maybe he wouldn't have drunk it, but he did. So the contradiction here is between the handle's position (Evidence 13) and the hand used to drink (Testimony 4). Therefore, Evidence 13 and Testimony 4 contradict each other. So the answer would be {"evidence": 13, "testimony": 4}.

Wait, but let me check again. Testimony 4: "the little fidget picked up the cup with his free hand and took a sip." His free hand would be the left hand, since the right was holding the newspaper (Testimony 1: newspaper in right hand). The cup's handle is on the right. If he's holding it with his left hand, the handle would be on the opposite side, making it difficult to hold. Therefore, the position of the handle (right side) suggests it was meant to be held with the right hand, but the testimony says he used his left. This inconsistency could mean that he couldn't have held the cup properly, implying someone else might have placed it there, contradicting the testimony. Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 13 and Testimony 4.
